ch.ecma.csta.system

Interface SystemServices


  • public interface SystemServices
    A set of services that allow an application to query and receive events on the status of Tlink connection(s) to the switch(es).

    Prerequisites Before attempting to use SystemServices, do the following:

    1. Acquire an instance of ServiceProvider by using the ServiceProvider.getServiceProvider method.
    2. Acquire an instance of SystemServices by using the ServiceProvider.getService method.

    Note that all supported SystemServices requests are also available through AsynchronousServices.sendRequest. Consider using this service when you would like to not block your application while waiting for the response.


    Version:
    6.2
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.

    • Method Detail

      • cancelSystemRegistration

        SystemRegisterCancelResponse cancelSystemRegistration(SystemRegisterCancel request)
                                               throws CstaException
        The SystemRegisterCancel request allows the application to cancel a previous System Registration.

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use SystemRegisterCancel.
        Receiving the response is an indication that the request succeeded. 

           SystemRegisterCancel request = new SystemRegisterCancel();
   
   // Cancel the registration using the registerId from a previous system registration
   request.setSysStatRegisterID(registerId);
   SystemRegisterCancelResponse response = sysSvcs.cancelSystemRegistration(request);
        Parameters:
        request - a SystemRegisterCancel service request
        request - A SystemRegisterCancel request that contains the systStatRegisterID to cancel a previous registration.
        Returns:
        A SystemRegisterCancelResponse
        Throws:
        InvalidCrossRefIDException - Thrown if the specified registerID is null, does not exist or does not belong to the current session.
        InvalidParameterException - Thrown if the SystemRegisterCancel request is malformed.
        CstaException - Thrown if an implementation specific error occurred during processing.

      • changeSystemStatusFilter

        ChangeSysStatFilterResponse changeSystemStatusFilter(ChangeSysStatFilter request)
                                              throws CstaException
        This service allows the application to modify the filter used for System Status notifications for a previous System Registration. The application can filter those System Status events that it does not wish to receive.

        The supported System Status Types are:

        • Normal
        • Disabled

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use ChangeSysStatFilter to filter Normal SystemStatusEvents and allow Disabled SystemStatusEvents.
        Note that receiving the response is an indication that the request succeeded. 

           ChangeSysStatFilter request = new ChangeSysStatFilter();
   request.setSysStatRegisterID(registerId);
   StatusFilterList filterList = new StatusFilterList();
   filterList.setNormal(true); // filter (i.e. don't allow)
   filterList.setDisabled(false); // don't filter (i.e. allow)
   request.setRequestedStatusFilter(filterList);
   ChangeSysStatFilterResponse response = sysSvcs.changeSystemStatusFilter(request);

        Alternatively, the following code achieves the same result, but uses the optional ChangeSysStatFilterPrivateData object to reverse the sense of the filter. 

           ChangeSysStatFilter request = new ChangeSysStatFilter();
   ChangeSysStatFilterPrivateData privData = new ChangeSysStatFilterPrivateData();

   // set the invertFilter
   privData.setInvertFilter(true); // true = reverse the sense of the filter
   CSTACommonArguments commArg = new CSTACommonArguments();
   commArg.setSinglePrivateData(privData);
   request.setExtensions(commArg);
   
   request.setSysStatRegisterID(registerId);
   StatusFilterList filterList = new StatusFilterList();
   filterList.setNormal(false); // filter (don't allow) because invertFilter=true
   filterList.setDisabled(true); // don't filter (allow) because invertFilter=true
   request.setRequestedStatusFilter(filterList);
   ChangeSysStatFilterResponse response = sysSvcs.changeSystemStatusFilter(request);

        Throws:
        CstaException - for any future exceptions.

      • registerSystem

        SystemRegisterResponse registerSystem(SystemRegister request)
                               throws CstaException
        The SystemRegister request allows the application to register for changes in the status of one or all administered Tlink(s). The application can register to receive a SystemStatus request each time the status of the Tlink changes. The service request includes a filter so the application can filter those status events that are not of interest to the application. The SystemRegisterPrivateData object is set in the request to register for status changes for one or all Tlinks.

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use SystemRegister and optional SystemRegisterPrivateData.

           SystemRegister request = new SystemRegister();
   SystemRegisterPrivateData privData = new SystemRegisterPrivateData();
   
   // set the switchName to blank or null to register for notification 
   // of all switch connections
   privData.setSwitchName("");
   // OR specify a switchName to register for notification for a single switch
   privData.setSwitchName("mySwitch");
   // set the invertFilter
   privData.setInvertFilter(true); // true = invert the sense of the filter
   
   CSTACommonArguments commArg = new CSTACommonArguments();
   commArg.setSinglePrivateData(privData);
   request.setExtensions(commArg);
   
   // Set the mandatory parameter RequestTypes
   RequestTypes rtype = new RequestTypes();
   rtype.setSystemStatus(true);
   request.setRequestTypes(rtype);
   
   // Optional Status Filter
   // Only the Normal and Disabled Events are supported.
   // Sending request without a filter defaults to all supported
   // events (i.e. Normal and Disabled) are allowed.
   // Optionally, you can explicitly specify them in the filter:
   StatusFilter filter = new StatusFilter();
   filter.setDisabled(true); // don't filter (allow) because invertFilter=true
   filter.setNormal(true); // don't filter (allow) because invertFilter=true
   request.setRequestedStatusFilter(filter);
   
   // Send the request
   SystemRegisterResponse response = sysSvcs.registerSystem(request);
   
   // Get the systemRegister ID from the response
   // This identifies the registration
   // SystemStatus requests will contain this ID when the status of the Tlink changes.
   String registerId = response.getSysStatRegisterID();
        Parameters:
        request - a SystemRegister service request
        request - A SystemRegister request that contains a switchName to register for Tlink status changes for the specified switch (or all switches when the switchName is blank or null).

        Optional parameters are supported in the private data area with an Avaya-specified SystemRegisterPrivateData} object.

        Returns:
        A SystemRegisterResponse
        Throws:
        ResourceOutOfServiceException - Thrown if the a system registrations failed for all the switches in the request
        CstaException - Thrown if an implementation specific error occurred.

      • requestSystemStatus

        RequestSystemStatusResponse requestSystemStatus(RequestSystemStatus request)
                                         throws CstaException
        The RequestSystemStatus request allows the application to query the Tlink status for one or all Tlink connections that are administered. This is a snapshot look at the status of the Tlinks. The aggregate status of all the Tlinks and the status of each Tlink is returned in the response when the application queries the status for all Tlinks.

        Optional parameters are supported in the private data area with an Avaya-specified RequestSystemStatusPrivateData object. The RequestSystemStatusPrivateData is set by the application to request the status of a single Tlink or all Tlinks.

        The RequestSystemStatusResponsePrivateData contains the status of each Tlink.

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use RequestSystemStatus.

         
  // create the reqeust
  RequestSystemStatus request = new RequestSystemStatus();
  
  // To get the Tlink status of one or more configured switches,
  // add private data to the request.
  RequestSystemStatusPrivateData privData = new RequestSystemStatusPrivateData();        
  GetTlinkStatus linkstat = new GetTlinkStatus();
         
  // set the switchName to blank or null to request status 
  // of all Tlink-to-switch connections
  linkstat.setSwitchName("");
  // OR specify a switchName to get the status of a Tlink connection to a switch
  linkstat.setSwitchName("mySwitch");        
  privData.setGetTlinkStatus(linkstat);
  
  CSTACommonArguments commArg = new CSTACommonArguments();
  commArg.setSinglePrivateData(privData);
  request.setExtensions(commArg);
   
  RequestSystemStatusResponse response = sysSvcs.requestSystemStatus(request);
  // Get the statusValue from the response
  // Disabled if all the Tlinks queried are down
  // Normal if all the Tlinks queried are up
  // PartiallyDisabled if at least one Tlink is up and one Tlink is down
  SystemStatusValue statusValue = response.getSystemStatus();
  if ((response.getExtensions() != null) && (response.getExtensions().getSinglePrivateData() 
      instanceof RequestSystemStatusResponsePrivateData)) {      
      
      RequestSystemStatusResponsePrivateData respPrivData = 
      (RequestSystemStatusResponsePrivateData)response.getExtensions().getSinglePrivateData();
      
      SwitchTlinkStatus[] switchTlinkStatus = new SwitchTlinkStatus[respPrivData.getSwitchTlinkStatusCount()];
      switchTlinkStatus = respPrivData.getSwitchTlinkStatus();
      for (SwitchTlinkStatus current:switchTlinkStatus) {
        System.out.println("switchname" + current.getSwitchName());
        System.out.println("tlinkStatus" + current.getTlinkStatus());
      }
  }
        See the RequestSystemStatus request for more information.

        Parameters:
        request - a RequestSystemStatus service request that contains a switchName to request the status of one or all administered Tlink connections
        Returns:
        A RequestSystemStatusResponse Optional parameters are supported in the private data area with an Avaya-specified RequestSystemStatusPrivateDataResponse
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterException - is thrown when an invalid switchname is specified in the request
        CstaException - Thrown if an implementation specific error occurred.

      • addSystemStatusListener

        void addSystemStatusListener(java.lang.String switchName,
                             SystemListener listener)
                      throws CstaException
        Adds a listener to receive the system status requests when the status of a Tlink has changed.

        When a change in the Tlink status occurs, the corresponding listener callback is called. A default callback is provided by SystemAdapter for each possible event. The default callbacks do nothing. If you want to act upon events, you can customize the events' callbacks for your application in either of the following ways:

        • Provide an implementation of every callback method in the SystemListener interface with a class that implements SystemListener.
        • Provide an implementation of a subset of callback methods with a class that extends SystemAdapter.

        Each listener is notified of events; the corresponding callback will be called on each listener that has been added.

        Parameters:
        switchName - the name of the switch whose Tlink status is to be monitored
        listener - the system status listener being applied. The listener may be an implementation of the SystemListener interface or an extension of SystemAdapter. If the specified listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Throws:
        CstaException - for any future exceptions.

      • removeSystemStatusListener

        void removeSystemStatusListener(SystemListener listener)
                         throws CstaException
        Removes a previously specified system status listener. It is possible for a callback to be issued on a listener after it has been removed. If no listeners have been added, then nothing happens when an event occurs.

        If the specified listener is not one that was previously added, then no exception is thrown and no function is performed. Also, if the specified listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.

        Parameters:
        listener - the system status listener being removed.
        Throws:
        CstaException - for any future exceptions.

      • getTimeOfDay

        GetTimeOfDayResponse getTimeOfDay(GetTimeOfDay request)
                           throws CstaException
        The getTimeOfDay request allows the application to query the switch information for the year, month, day, hour, minute and second.

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use GetTimeOfDay.
        time-of-day information will be included in the response if request is successful. 

           GetTimeOfDay request = new GetTimeOfDay();
   
   //set the switch Name for which the time of day should be obtained
   request.setSwitchName("YourSwitchName");
   //send the request
   GetTimeOfDayResponse response = sysSvcs.getTimeOfDay(request);
   
   //get the time of day information for specified switch name
   int year      = response.getYear();
   int month     = response.getMonth();
   int day       = response.getDay();
   int hour      = response.getHour();
   int minute    = response.getMinute();
   int second    = response.getSecond();
        Parameters:
        request - a GetTimeOfDay service request
        Returns:
        A GetTimeOfDayResponse
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - is thrown when an invalid or null switchname is specified in the request
        CstaException - Thrown if an implementation specific error occurred.
